children.value: to open a HEALPix data catalog
package to look at basic statistics over HEALPix data
Using UXarray plotting functionality on HEALPix data
Working with HEALPix data - UXarray documentation
UXarray overview - Unstructured Grids Visualization Cookbook
Data visualization with UXarray - Unstructured Grids Visualization Cookbook

import cartopy.crs as ccrs
import uxarray as ux

children.value: If you think that you first need to learn about Intake, Pythia’s
is a great resource to do so.
Let us use the online data catalog from the WCRP’s Digital Earths Global Hackathon 2025’s
and read the output of the
, which is stored in the HEALPix format:
This section uses the same data and will showcase similar operations as the
, e.g. basic statistics and global and regional data plotting, except at the end where further grid exploration methods will be demonstrated.

import intake

# Hackathon data catalogs
cat_url = "https://digital-earths-global-hackathon.github.io/catalog/catalog.yaml"
cat = intake.open_catalog(cat_url).online
model_run = cat.icon_ngc4008
We will be looking at two resolution levels, one is the coarsest zoom level of 0, which is the default in this model run, and the other is a finer one at the zoom level of 7:

children.value: Let us look at the global and Boulder, CO, USA air temperature averages for the dataset. Data spans from 2020 to 2050, so let us also consider slicing it to have a 3-year interval between 2020 and 2023, which would also give us similar results to that with easy.gems in the

import matplotlib.pylab as plt

boulder_lon = -105.2747
boulder_lat = 40.0190

time_slice = slice("2020-01-02T00:00:00.000000000", "2023-01-01T00:00:00.000000000")
We can find face(s) containing a given point with

children.value: In order to use in the rest of the analyses, we can grab data variables, in the
type, from the dataset as follows:
In order to get a line plot of our
objects’ 1-dimensional temperature variables, we will convert them to
function because UXarray’s default plotting functions are all dedicated to grid-topology aware visualizations:

data.traceback:
[31m---------------------------------------------------------------------------[39m
[31mNameError[39m                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
[36mFile [39m[32m<timed exec>:1[39m

[31mNameError[39m: name 'boulder_face' is not defined

children.value: UXarray provides several built-in plotting functions to visualize unstructured grids, which can also be applied to HEALPix grids in the same interface:
Let us first look into interactive plots with the
backend (i.e. UXarray’s plotting functions have a
parameter that defaults to “bokeh”, and it can also accept “matplotlib”)
Let us first plot the global temperature (at the first timestep for simplicity), using the default backend,
, of UXarray’s visualization API to create an interactive plot:

%%time

projection = ccrs.Robinson(central_longitude=-135.5808361)

uxda_fine.isel(time=0).plot(
    projection=projection,
    cmap="inferno",
    features=["borders", "coastline"],
    title="Global temperature",
    width=700,
)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
CPU times: user 10.9 s, sys: 676 ms, total: 11.5 s
Wall time: 13.8 s

data.name: stderr
data.text: WARNING:param.GeoOverlayPlot00481: Due to internal constraints, when aspect and width/height is set, the bokeh backend uses those values as frame_width/frame_height instead. This ensures the aspect is respected, but means that the plot might be slightly larger than anticipated. Set the frame_width/frame_height explicitly to suppress this warning.

children.value: Now, let us create the same plot, using

%%time

uxda_fine.isel(time=0).plot(
    backend="matplotlib",
    projection=projection,
    cmap="inferno",
    features=["borders", "coastline"],
    title="Global temperature",
    width=1100,
)

children.value: Regional subsets (Not only for plotting but also for analysis)

children.label: Regional subsets (Not only for plotting but also for analysis)

children.value: When a region on the globe is of interest, UXarray provides subsetting functions, which return new regional grids that can then be used in the same way a global grid is plotted.
Let us look into the USA map using the Boulder, CO, USA coords we had used before for simplicity:
using a “bounding box” around Boulder, CO first:

%%time

lon_bounds = (boulder_lon - 20, boulder_lon + 40)
lat_bounds = (boulder_lat - 20, boulder_lat + 12)

uxda_fine_subset = uxda_fine.isel(time=0).subset.bounding_box(lon_bounds, lat_bounds)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
CPU times: user 1min 7s, sys: 2.45 s, total: 1min 9s
Wall time: 1min 7s

children.value: If we check the global and regional subset’s average temperature at the first timestep, we can see the difference:
Now, let us plot the regional subset

%%time
projection = ccrs.Robinson(central_longitude=boulder_lon)

uxda_fine_subset.plot(
    projection=projection,
    cmap="inferno",
    features=["borders", "coastline"],
    title="Boulder temperature",
    width=1100,
)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
CPU times: user 65.8 ms, sys: 49 μs, total: 65.9 ms
Wall time: 64.8 ms

children.value: Exploring the grid topology may be needed sometimes, and UXarray provides functionality to do so, both numerically and visually. Each
object that has all the information such as spherical and cartesian coordinates, connectives, dimensions, etc. about the topology this data belongs to. This
object can be explored as follows:

# uxds_fine.uxgrid   # this would give the same as the below
uxda_fine.uxgrid

children.value: There might be times that the user wants to open a standalone
object for a HEALPix grid (or any other unstructured grids supported by UXarray) without accessing the data yet. Let’s create the coarsest HEALPix grid as follows:

text/plain.content:
<uxarray.Grid>
Original Grid Type: HEALPix
Grid Dimensions:
  * n_node: 14
  * n_face: 12
  * n_max_face_nodes: 4
Grid Coordinates (Spherical):
  * node_lon: (14,)
  * node_lat: (14,)
  * face_lon: (12,)
  * face_lat: (12,)
Grid Coordinates (Cartesian):
Grid Connectivity Variables:
  * face_node_connectivity: (12, 4)
Grid Descriptor Variables:

children.value: Let’s investigate how a HEALPix grid looks like over the poles. We can do things by selecting an Orthographic projection and setting a Geodetic source projection. This allows to better approximates the true HEALPix structured compared to the defaut PlateCaree projection.

projection = ccrs.Orthographic(central_latitude=90)
projection.threshold /= 100  # Smoothes out great circle arcs

uxgrid.plot(
    periodic_elements="ignore",  # Allow Cartopy to handle periodic elements
    crs=ccrs.Geodetic(),  # Enables edges to be plotted as GCAs
    project=True,
    projection=projection,
    width=500,
    title="HEALPix (Orthographic Proj), zoom=0",
)

projection = ccrs.Mollweide()
projection.threshold /= 100  # Smoothes out great circle arcs

uxgrid.plot(
    periodic_elements="ignore",  # Allow Cartopy to handle periodic elements
    crs=ccrs.Geodetic(),  # Enables edges to be plotted as GCAs
    project=True,
    projection=projection,
    width=500,
    title="HEALPix (Mollweide Proj), zoom=0",
)

The grid structure here is approximated. While the boundary between each pixel is easily known in HEALPix workflows, UXarray represents the boundaries as a Great Circle Arc (GCA) due to the requirement of having explicit connectivity information, which is different than HEALPix boundaries and leads to minor differences in the computed plots and computations.
Now that we’ve looked at the grid structure, we can also apply the same principles to our data plotting.
Using the Geodetic source projection is not reccomended for higher-resolution grids, as it introduces a significant overhead.

uxda_coarsest.isel(time=0).plot(
    periodic_elements="ignore",  # Allow Cartopy to handle periodic elements
    crs=ccrs.Geodetic(),  # Enables edges to be plotted as GCAs
    project=True,
    projection=projection,
    features=["borders", "coastline"],
    cmap="inferno",
    title="Temperature (Mollweide Proj), zoom=0",
    width=500,
)
will provide an UXarray workflow that loads in and analyzes & visualizes HEALPix data.

next.title: UXarray for Advanced HEALPix Analysis & Visualization
